Low-temperature selective catalytic reduction of NOx with ammonia (NH3-SCR) over zeolite catalysts remains a great challenge in diesel exhaust purification. Herein, Cu-LTA zeolite with excellent hydrothermal stability was composited with a small proportion of SmMnOx oxides, the composite catalytic system efficiently resolves the low-temperature activity challenge encountered by Cu-LTA. The promoting pathways revealed the presence of active nitrite intermediates formed on SmMnOx by activating NO, that were able to migrate to the Cu-LTA and can be further decomposed on the Brønsted acid sites. Compared to the continuous deposition of nitrates in Cu-LTA, the presence of SmMnOx in composite catalysts efficiently reduced the accumulation of inert nitrate and improved the nitrate deposition phenomena. This innovative research would provide a rational strategy to break the barrier of limited low-temperature performance faced by zeolite catalysts, effectively promoting the NOx removal in vehicles sources. Graphical Abstract Keywords Selective catalytic reduction NOx reduction Air pollution control Environmental catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Transportation has emerged as a significant environmental concern, due to the inescapable liberation of nitrogen oxides (NOx) from combustion engines [1,2]. These NOx pollutants exert a notable influence on environment and human health [3]. Over the past two decades, the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology was applied for the commercial implementation of to curb NOx emission [4–6]. Copper-exchanged CHA zeolite catalysts, such as Cu-SSZ-13, have garnered extensive attention and found commercial applications for reducing NOx emissions. Despite its widespread use, Cu-SSZ-13 not only exhibits limited effectiveness in completely removing NOx but also experiences deactivation at elevated temperatures. For instance, following hydrothermal aging at 850 °C, there is a considerable decrease in porosity and surface area, leading to a substantial loss of activity [7–9]. Consequently, the development of more robust zeolites is imperative for the advancement of the next generation of NOx reduction catalysts. LTA zeolite was initially discovered as type A [10,11], belonging to the class of small pore zeolites that can be synthesized with various organic structural directing agents. In contrast to the deactivation experienced by Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts, high silicon (SiAl = 16–23) LTA zeolite in the form of copper exchange (CuAl = 0.50) could retain structural integrity and high NH3-SCR activity even under severe hydrothermal aging conditions of up to 900 °C [11–13]. Despite the commendable hydrothermal stability of Cu-LTA catalysts [14,15], they still suffer from lower low-temperature NH3-SCR efficiency even than that of Cu-SSZ-13 [12]. Due to increasingly stringent exhaust emission regulations and the development of advanced engines that maximize fuel efficiency, i.e., cooler engine exhaust, enhancing the low-temperature efficiency of the current catalytic reduction system has become a critical focus [16,17]. NOx can be reduced to innocuous N2 through “standard SCR” reaction (4NO + 4NH3 + O2 → 4 N2 + 6 H2O), but the efficient conversion cannot be achieved at low temperatures (< 200 °C). The “Fast SCR” process, which can occur with equal moles of NO in the presence of NO2 (NO + NO2 + 2NH3 → 2 N2 + 3 H2O) [18–21], relies on the conversion of a portion of NO emitted from diesel engines to NO2 via diesel oxidation catalysts (DOC) located upstream of the SCR catalysts. Nevertheless, the occurrence of this process is still limited, especially in small-pore zeolite catalysts [22,23]. Recent efforts have shown that the integration of zeolite with metal oxides, such as MnCeTiOx/Cu-SSZ-13 [24], Mn/Ce-SSZ-13 [25], ZrO2/Cu-SSZ-13 [26], can enhance low-temperature NOx reduction. This integration involves combining DOC and SCR catalysts into a composite catalyst system, where the introduced metal oxides facilitate the activation and oxidation of NO. However, the intermediates involved in the interaction between zeolite and metal oxides have not been clarified yet, and diverse opinions persist regarding the influence of the aqueous environment on the composite catalyst system in NH3-SCR reaction. Based on these findings, screening for the most efficacious metal oxides and the integration with Cu-LTA presents a promising avenue for markedly enhancing the low-temperature efficiency of Cu-LTA zeolite and elucidating the potential mechanisms. Manganese oxides (MnOx) have been recognized as the most efficient catalysts for the low-temperature NH3-SCR of NOx among transition-metal oxides [27–29]. Nevertheless, pure MnOx suffers from inadequate thermal durability and a restricted surface, severely restricted its commercial applications. Introducing a secondary element, such as Fe-Mn and Ce-Mn mixed oxides, has been demonstrated to augment the number of defects and the surface area in MnOx [23,30]. According to experimental evidence in the literature, it has been observed that the addition of Sm to MnOx leads to an increase in the relative contents of surface Mn4+ and surface oxygen (OS) on SmMnOx. This increase promotes the activation of nitrate adsorbed on the surface of SmMnOx catalyst, resulting in a substantial enhancement of the catalytic performance of NH3-SCR [31]. Our analysis of the literature, along with our own verification and comparative studies, supports this conclusion. Nonetheless, the SmMnOx catalysts still confront challenges such as high temperature resistance and poor N2 selectivity, especially in aqueous environments where NH3-SCR activity is severely hindered. Herein, the Cu-LTA zeolite with outstanding hydrothermal stability and excellent N2 selectivity has been employed as a SCR component. The SmMnOx catalysts, prepared through coprecipitation, have been selected as the selective catalytic oxidation component. While metal oxides typically exhibit heightened oxidation tendencies leading to lower N2 selectivity compared to zeolites, the composite catalytic system efficiently resolves the low-temperature activity challenge encountered by Cu-LTA while maintaining acceptable N2O levels. Furthermore, the effects of aqueous environment on NH3-SCR reaction were effectively assessed. Remarkably, multiple characterization techniques were employed to analyze the promotional effect of SmMnOx on Cu-LTA, leading to the proposal of a potential mechanism of action under low-temperature conditions. 2 Experiments methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation LTA zeolite owning a Si/Al ratio of 15 was prepared following the procedure reported by Wang et al. [11] , with only minor changes. First, organic structure directing agent (OSDA) was synthesized, and the obtained OSDA was then converted into hydroxide OSDA by anion exchange resin and titrating with 0.1 M hydrochloric acid. After that, the zeolite was synthesized according to the gel molar composition (15OSDA: 2TMAOH: 15HF: 30SiO2: 1Al2O3: 150 H2O). Hydrothermal synthesis was carried out in a sand bath at 175 °C for a duration of four days with continuous stirring, and the artificial zeolite was calcined in static air at 600 °C for 8 hours to remove OSDA. The Si/Al ratio of 15.6 was verified via inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). The initial wet impregnation (IWI) method mentioned in the literature was used to prepare x wt% Cu-LTA (x = 1.5, 2.0, 2.4 abbreviated as x%Cu-LTA) [32] . Table S1 shows the Cu loading amount, Cu/Al and Si /Al ratios of 2.0 %Cu-LTA. The coprecipitation method mentioned in the literature was used to prepare SmMnOx oxide catalysts with some modifications [31] . Generally, the required amount of Sm(NO3)3·6 H2O and MnSO4·H2O was dissolved in an appropriate amount of deionized water, and then both the mixing solution and the 0.2 M Na2CO3 solution were added to the beaker and kept stirring whilst maintaining pH at 9. After mixing for 4 hours, the resulting solid product was filtered, dried overnight at 120 °C, ultimately calcined in air at a temperature of 450 °C for 4 hours. The prepared catalyst was named as SmMnOx (abbreviated as SM in the composite catalysts). Composite catalysts were prepared using three methods: mixing, grinding and sol-gel method. For the mixing process, the powdered catalyst mixture was thoroughly shaken in different proportions in test tubes. During the grinding process, the same proportion of powdered catalyst mixture was put in an agate mortar and ground thoroughly for 1 hour. There was another tiny modification on the composite catalysts synthesized by sol-gel method following the procedure reported by Wang et al. [33] , the specific process was included in the Supporting Information (SI). In the following discussion, (m), (g), (s) are respectively used to represent powder mixing, grinding, and sol-gel methods. For example, the catalytic components are respectively represented as SM(y)/x%Cu-LTA(z)(m), SM(y)/x%Cu-LTA(z)(g), and SM(y)/x%Cu-LTA(z)(s) (y and z represent weight ratios of SM and x%Cu-LTA, y = 1 and z = 1, 4, 9, 19). 2.2 Catalyst activity The NH3-SCR performance assessments were conducted in a fixed bed quartz tube flow reactor with an internal diameter of 4 mm. Each catalyst was weighed 0.092 g and sieved between 40 and 60 mesh. The experimental gas flow was 255 mL/min (GHSV = 100000 h−1), consisting of 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 5 vol% O2, 5 vol% H2O, and balanced N2. The concentrations of NH3, NO, NO2, and N2O were continuously monitored using an FT-IR spectrometer (Bruker IMatrix- MGX). The GHSV, NOx conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated by the following equation: (1) NO x conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − [ NO x ] out [ NO x ] in ) × 100 % (2) GHSV = q v πh r 2 (3) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = ( 1 − 2 N 2 O out ( [ NO x ] in − [ NO x ] out ) + ( [ NH 3 ] in − [ NH 3 ] out ) ) × 100 % Where NOx represents the total concentration of NO and NO2, [NOx]in and [NOx]out represent the inlet and outlet gas concentration, respectively. [N2O]out represent the outlet gas concentration of N2O. The reaction rate was calculated by the equation: (4) R = F NO x × X NO x 22.44 W × X a Where FNOx is the NOx concentration of inlet NOx molecules (L·min−1), XNOx is the NOx conversion, W is the weight of the catalysts (g), Xa is the atomic percentage of Mn from X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results or element content of Cu from ICP results. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The effect of different pathways in compositing Cu-LTA zeolite with SmMnOx on low-temperature NH3-SCR performance has been investigated. As shown in Fig. 1a, NOx conversion is significantly improved by the addition of SmMnOx component, especially for SM(1)/2.0 %Cu-LTA(9)(m), as compared to SM(1)/2.0 %Cu-LTA(9)(s) and SM(1)/2.0 %Cu-LTA(9)(g) (the 1:9 of ratio and the 2.0 % of Cu loading are omitted in this figure), demonstrating a wide operation window of 180–400 °C with the NOx conversion above 80 % (Fig. S1). For a more intuitive comparison of the improvement in NH3-SCR performance in the low temperature range of 120–240 °C, Fig. 1b shows the NOx conversion of 2.0 %Cu-LTA and SM(1)/2.0 %Cu-LTA(9)(m) in the form of histograms. In particular, an improvement of over 60 % in the conversion has been achieved at 180 °C. Meanwhile, the N2 selectivity exceed 85 % for SM(1)/2.0 %Cu-LTA(9)(m) catalysts, as shown by the dashed line in Fig. 1b. The variation of N2O concentration in the temperature range of 120–400 °C for all the catalysts mentioned above show noticeable differences in the N2 selectivity of NH3-SCR reaction (Fig. S2). When varying the ratios between metal oxides and zeolite, it can be found that the composite catalysts with a ratio of 1:9 for SmMnOx and 2.0 %Cu-LTA demonstrate the significantly enhanced NH3-SCR performance of low-temperature and the broader temperature window (Fig. S3). We also conducted NOx reduction tests on Cu-LTA with different Cu loadings and composite catalysts prepared by mixing with SmMnOx (1:9) under the same conditions (Fig. S4). The low-temperature performance of 2.4 %Cu-LTA closely parallels that of 2.0 %Cu-LTA, with a marginal decline observed around 300 °C, potentially attributed to the formation of inert species during synthesis, such as intermediates poised to evolve into copper oxides. Contrastingly, 1.5 %Cu-LTA exhibits notably inferior NOx conversion, likely stemming from a deficiency in active Cu species, a deduction supported by extant literature [12] . Our objective herein is to identify Cu-LTA possessing superior activity to serve as the benchmark for composite catalysts through comparative analysis. Consequently, we opted to employ 2.0 %Cu-LTA for composite with oxides. We also confirm the optimal conditions by varying proportions and preparation methods using the composite catalysts prepared by SmMnOx and 1.5 %Cu-LTA (Fig. S5, S6, S7). These findings suggest a synergistic effect between metal oxides and Cu-LTA zeolite during the NH3-SCR reaction. To explore its reaction mechanism, further study will mainly focus on SM(1)/2.0 %Cu-LTA(9)(m) with the best performance obtained from the above screening conditions (abbreviated as SM/Cu-LTA(m)). SM/Cu-LTA(s), SM/Cu-LTA(g) and Cu-LTA are also used for comparison. Furthermore, we have augmented the calculation of the reaction rates of SM/Cu-LTA(m) and Cu-LTA catalysts based on the Cu cation content obtained from ICP results ( Fig. 2a), and the calculation of the reaction rates of SM/Cu-LTA(m) and SmMnOx catalysts based on the Mn content obtained from XPS results (Fig. 2b). The reaction rate of SM/Cu-LTA(m) is considerably higher than that of Cu-LTA in the low temperature range, and the reaction rate above 240 ℃ is relatively similar. While the reaction rate of SmMnOx is higher than that of SM/Cu-LTA(m) at low temperature, it exhibits a significant reaction rate advantage of composite catalysts above 180 ℃. In comparison to pure Cu-LTA and SmMnOx, despite a reduction in the content of both components in the composite catalyst, the composite catalyst exhibits enhanced activity following the normalization of the reaction rate using Cu sites and surface Mn sites as reference values. This suggests that the synergistic effect of the two components is necessary to achieve a balance between activity and selectivity. H-LTA with negligible standard SCR performance instead of Cu-LTA was composited with SmMnOx under above optimum conditions, named as SM/H-LTA(m). The comparison between the NOx conversion of SM/H-LTA(m) and SM/Cu-LTA(m) clearly demonstrates the positive effect of Cu in promoting the NH3-SCR reaction as the active site of the zeolite in the composite catalysts (Fig. S8). SM/SiO2(m) was obtained by the same method, with SiO2 replacing H-LTA. Due to the inertness of SiO2 in the NH3-SCR reaction, the performance of SM/SiO2(m) highlights the cooperative effect between metal oxides and zeolite (Fig. S9a). The NOx conversion of pure SmMnOx was also investigated at the same airspeed, exhibiting excellent low-temperature activity (Fig. S10). Meanwhile, the comparison of NOx conversion between SM/H-LTA and SM/SiO2 indicates that the Brønsted acid sites of H-LTA (without Cu sites) play a significant role in the synergistic effect on the two components in composite catalysts. Compared to SM/SiO2(m), SM/Cu-LTA(m) shows significantly superior N2 selectivity in NH3-SCR reaction (Fig. S9b). While SmMnOx typically exhibit heightened oxidation tendencies leading to lower N2 selectivity compared to zeolites, our approach excels in low-temperature performance, maintaining acceptable N2O levels. To further verify its ability to resist hydrothermal aging, the composite catalyst was subjected to hydrothermal aging treatment at 600 °C for 48 hours (the specific process was included in the SI), and the activity tests were then conducted (Fig. S11). The results indicate that the composite catalyst experiences a slight decrease in NOx conversion after hydrothermal aging. Nevertheless, it still demonstrates relatively good low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. In addition, the SO2 resistance of SmMnOx/Cu-LTA composite catalyst was investigated (Fig. S12 ), the specific process was included in the SI. Due to the poor sulfur resistance of Cu-LTA and the small addition of SmMnOx in the composite catalyst, the activity data shows that it has not improved the sulfur resistance of Cu-LTA. Due to the inevitable presence of a large amount of H2O in the exhaust gas of combustion engines, the addition of H2O to the test is closer to practical operating conditions [10,34]. For investigating the impact of H2O on the behavior of Cu-LTA and SM/Cu-LTA(m) in NH3-SCR, we conducted the tests under the reaction conditions with or without H2O. In the following discussion, (D) and (W) represent dry and wet conditions, respectively, such as Cu-LTA(D), Cu-LTA(W), SM/Cu-LTA(m)(D) and SM/Cu-LTA(m)(W) (Fig. S13). For Cu-LTA, the performance is significantly enhanced under reaction conditions with H2O. Related studies have shown that H2O significantly enhances the migration of Cu ions from spatially inaccessible sod cages to easily accessible lta cages and the formation of [H2O-Cu-NH3]+ intermediate, which tunes the active sites and reaction pathways [10] . We surprisingly find that the addition of H2O significantly inhibits the NH3-SCR performance of SM/Cu-LTA(m) at low temperatures (< 270 °C) but significantly promotes when the temperature is above 270 °C. A more incredible finding is that SM/Cu-LTA(m) exhibit significant differences in the production of N2O for the NH3-SCR reaction with or without H2O. Compared to anhydrous conditions, the production of N2O can be significantly reduced in the presence of H2O, previous literature has mentioned that H2O has a strong inhibition on NO reduction and N2O formation during the low-temperature SCR reaction[35] . It is speculated that the aqueous environment probably has a certain impact on the oxidation of metal oxides, the role of acid sites in zeolite, and the production and consumption of intermediate species during two-composite interactions. 3.2 Structure and reducibility analysis To study the crystal structure of catalysts, X-ray power diffraction (XRD) was conducted. Fig. 3a shows that the Cu zeolites exhibit characteristic peaks of LTA in the XRD patterns, indicating that the LTA structure has been synthesized successfully, and the structure remains unchanged after the addition of Cu ions. Meanwhile, the addition of Cu ions did not lead to the formation of copper-related phases (Cu, CuOx), with the XRD pattern of H-LTA shown for reference (Fig. 3b) [11,36]. The characteristic peaks for SmMnOx in XRD pattern indicated that the main crystal phase was MnO2 (PDF#30–0820), with Mn3O4 (PDF#18–0803) also observed. The composite catalysts present the characteristic peaks of LTA in Fig. 3b, with no peaks for SmMnOx observed. The result can be illustrated by the overlapping of the diffraction peaks, while also demonstrating the absence of significant oxide particles and revealing the uniform dispersion of oxides within the samples. Meanwhile, the results of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Fig. S14) and mapping images (Fig. S15) verify the relatively uniform distribution of Cu-LTA and trace amounts of SmMnOx in the composite catalysts. The redox properties of Cu-LTA and composite catalysts were assessed by temperature programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR). As shown in Fig. 4a, two distinct reduction peaks can be observed in the Cu-LTA samples centred around 268 °C and 476 °C, with an obvious shoulder at approximately 364 °C. It is expected that [Cu(OH)]+ exhibit a lower temperature reduction peak, owing to the decreased binding energy between the framework and [Cu(OH)]+ in comparison to Cu2+. Consequently, the peak at 268 °C and the higher temperature peak at 476 °C may be due to the reduction of [Cu(OH)]+ and Cu2+(Z2Cu), respectively. The reduction shoulder at 364°C and the subsequent peak at 598 °C may reflect the reduction of CuOx clusters and the reduction of Cu+, respectively. SmMnOx has a strong reduction peak compared to zeolite and the consumption of H2 by Cu ions in zeolite is much lower than the lattice oxygen in metal oxides. The reduction peak observed near 240 °C is likely due to the reduction of MnO2/Mn2O3 → Mn3O4, whereas the peak at the higher temperature near 385 °C is attributed to the reduction of Mn3O4/Mn5O8 → MnO [31]. The reduction peak intensity of the SM/Cu-LTA(m) is between that of pure zeolite and metal oxides in Fig. 4b. Due to the significantly weaker reduction peak intensity of Cu-LTA compared to SmMnOx, similar H2-TPR curves are obtained in SM/Cu-LTA(m) and SmMnOx. Notably, the relative intensity of the reduction peaks of Mn4+ and Mn3+ in the SmMnOx and SM/Cu-LTA(m) catalysts remains largely unchanged, indicating that the chemical transformation of Mn species is not significant. Although the two reduction peaks in SM/Cu-LTA(m) shift towards lower temperatures, this is because H2-TPR characterizes the overall reduction ability of the catalyst, and the overall reduction temperature of SM/Cu-LTA(m) is relatively low. The comparison of H2-TPR curves of SM/Cu-LTA(m), SM/Cu-LTA(s) and SM/Cu-LTA(g) was presented in Fig. 4b, with the H2 consumed by different species on each catalyst was computed from the area of reduction peaks (Table S2). The SM/Cu-LTA(s) composite catalyst is primarily reduced by Mn4+, exhibiting only a weak reduction peak of Mn3+. This is attributed to the alteration of oxides during the sol-gel preparation process, leading to changes in Mn valence. The notable increase in Mn4+ and the significant decrease in Mn3+ disrupt the oxygen adsorption and desorption equilibrium, as well as the electron transfer effect, which consequently affects the catalytic performance. In comparison to SM/Cu-LTA(m), the reduction peak of SM/Cu-LTA(g) shifts towards higher temperatures, accompanied by a slight decrease in the relative proportion of Mn4+ and Mn3+ reduction peaks. This is attributed to chemical state of Mn oxidizing species fluctuations during the grinding process, which has the effect of reducing the reduction performance. In the composite catalysts mixed in different proportions, the peak area increases with the increasing of SmMnOx mass ratio (Fig. S16), which is consistent with the previous conclusion that H2 consumption is mainly provided by metal oxides. To further investigate the chemical state of various catalysts, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of Mn 2p and O 1 s were studied in Fig. 5. The Mn 2p signals of SmMnOx and SM/Cu-LTA(m) displayed in Fig. 5a exhibit three distinct peaks. The peaks at 641 ± 0.3 eV and 642 ± 0.3 eV are indicative of Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively, with the peak at 643.5 eV being a satellite peak of manganese [31]. The ratio of Mn4+/Mn is similar in SmMnOx and SM/Cu-LTA(m) samples (Table S3), indicating the absence of any chemical interaction between the two phases subsequent to physical mixing. Fig. 5b shows the O1s spectrum, which can be divided into one peak at 531.5 eV and another at 529.6 eV in SmMnOx, namely the surface oxygen such as O- or O2 2- (named OS) and lattice oxygen O2- (named OL) [31] . The O 1 s spectrum of pure Cu-LTA displays a single balanced peak at 532.4 eV (Fig. S17), which is commonly referred to as surface oxygen. The XPS measurement only detected the surface elements of the substance, and the OL in the framework of Cu-LTA could not be measured. The O1s spectra of SM/Cu-LTA(m) reveal two peaks, namely at 529.8 eV and 532.7 eV. Notably, the former peak is OL, which is also observed in SmMnOx samples. The latter peak should overlap with the OS spectra of Cu-LTA and SmMnOx components, which shifted towards higher binding energy compared to pure Cu-LTA, suggesting that the contact environment of the two components may affect the bonding mode of adsorbed oxygen in the composite catalyst, resulting in a change in the binding energy. In the composite sample, lattice oxygen and chemically adsorbed oxygen are mainly provided by metal oxides and zeolite, respectively, verifying the synergistic effect of zeolites and metal oxides in the active Mn species maintaining as well as lattice oxygen and chemically adsorbed oxygen balance to facilitate the SCR reaction. 3.3 Acidity and adsorption behavior study To investigate the acidic properties of the catalysts, ammonia temperature-programmed desorption-mass spectrometry (NH3-TPD-MS) was carried out in Fig. 6. The NH3 desorption signals over the catalysts were split into three peaks according to the MS analysis. Weakly adsorbed NH3 on weak acid sites is responsible for the initial desorption peak (I) within the 190–220 °C temperature range. The intermediate peak (II) at 240–350 °C corresponds to NH3 adsorption on moderately strong acid sites. As for the final desorption peak (III) above 400 °C, it is ascribed to NH3 that is adsorbed on the strong acid site. By analyzing the NH3-TPD curve, the quantities of NH3 desorption at varying acid sites are given in Table S4. The integral area value of Cu-LTA is much higher than SmMnOx, which significantly indicates that Cu-LTA contains more strong Brønsted acidic sites. The NH3 desorption curves in the SM/Cu-LTA(m) and Cu-LTA samples are similar, as the curve of SmMnOx may overlap within Cu-LTA. The NH3-TPD curves of the composite catalysts prepared in different methods are shown in Fig. 6b. These curves are similar to the NH3 release curves in the Cu-LTA samples, with slightly differences in NH3 desorption. The lowest NH3 desorption is observed in SM/Cu-LTA(s), in which SmMnOx and Cu-LTA are complexed by citric acid, it is possible that the adsorption of NH3 by the Brønsted acid sites of the zeolite may be affected, resulting in a relative decrease in NOx removal efficiency. The NH3 desorption on SM/Cu-LTA(g) is very close to that on SM/Cu-LTA(m), and the relative decrease in NOx removal efficiency may be attributed to the blocking of the pores of the zeolite during grinding. Due to the distribution of Cu active sites in the complex internal structure of the zeolite and the difficulty in determining their forms, the covering of the pores may also affect the migration of active intermediate species generated in the synergistic effect to Cu sites. The NH3 desorption amount increases with the increase of Cu-LTA mass ratio in the composite catalysts mixed in different proportions (Fig. S18). To research the thermostability and the desorption behaviors of adsorbed NH3 species, in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) of NH3 desorption was characterized, as shown in Fig. 7. The peaks at 1196 cm−1, 1261 cm−1, 1320 cm−1, 1565 cm−1 and 1620 cm−1 correspond to the coordinated NH3 located on the Lewis acid sites, while peaks detected at 1450 cm−1 and 1464 cm−1 are attributed to the NH4 + ions that are bound to the Brønsted acid sites. The peaks at 3179–3354 cm−1 are attributed to the N-H stretching vibrational modes of NH3, which are coordinated to the Lewis acid sites [37] . The peaks at 3561 cm−1 and 3612 cm−1 belong to the depletion of Brønsted acid sites (Si-OH-Al) by NH3 adsorption [38,39], while the peaks at 3675 cm−1 and 3730 cm−1 belong to the depletion of the Al-OH sites and Si-OH sites by NH3 adsorption, respectively [8,11]. The NH3 located on the Lewis acid sites and the NH4 + located on the Brønsted acid sites are shortened as L-NH3 and B-NH4 +, respectively. The results show that the desorption rate of L-NH3 in the SM/Cu-LTA(m) is significantly higher than that in Cu-LTA, implying that the NH3 species are more unstable in the SM/Cu-LTA(m) and easier to participate in SCR reactions. Meanwhile, the Cu-LTA catalysts exhibit higher intensity for the peak of B-NH4 +, but NH3 migration rather than NH3 desorption occurs significantly as the temperature increased, which interferes with the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.4 Transient reaction mechanism investigation To investigate the species reactivity adsorbed on the surface of catalysts, reaction pathways of active intermediates and the synergistic mechanism within the composite catalysts, in situ DRIFT spectra of the transient reactions for Cu-LTA and SM/Cu-LTA(m) catalysts were executed at 180 °C. The transient reactions between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO + O2 can be seen in Fig. 8. After NO + O2 adsorption, six bands at 1592, 1564, 1508, 1434, 1342, and 1228 cm−1 are detected in Fig. 8a. The bands at 1592 and 1564 cm−1 are indicative of monodentate nitrate, while the bands at 1434 cm−1 corresponds to monodentate nitrite and the band at 1228 cm−1 is associated with bridged nitrate. Additionally, the bands at 1508 cm−1 and 1342 cm−1 are representative of other nitrates [40–45]. Following subsequent exposure to NH3, NOx adsorbed on the SM/Cu-LTA(m) gradually disappear. The coordinated NH3 (1606, 1262 and 1554 cm−1) and NH4 + (1445 cm−1) appear as shown in Fig. 8c [43,46–48]. The bands at 1228 and 1508 cm−1 have also been identified in Cu-LTA, as shown in Fig. 8b. An observable transformation is apparent, where the band at 1564 cm−1 changes into a monodentate nitrate adsorption peak at 1592 cm−1 with the increasing adsorption time. Furthermore, the band at 1342 cm−1 transforms to 1371 cm−1 attributed to N2O2 2- [49]. Obviously different from SM/Cu-LTA(m), there is no adsorption peak of nitrite at 1434 cm−1 in Cu-LTA. According to research, nitrite is a key intermediate in SCR reaction and an important product of NO oxidation activation. Additionally, it has been found to be more mobile than other nitrates [23]. Therefore, this unstable surface-active intermediate formation is likely the main driver for the enhancement of NH3-SCR performance. On the basis of the above experimental evidence, the SmMnOx demonstrates distinctive Mn4+ and Mn3+ signal peaks in XPS (Fig. 5), along with a discernible redox capacity towards Mn4+ and Mn3+ as observed in H2-TPR (Fig. 4). And the NO + O2 adsorption spectra on SmMnOx predominantly exhibits adsorption peaks of bidentate nitrate (1559 and 1281 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1033 cm−1) and bridging nitrate (1248 cm−1), with enhanced adsorption intensity (Fig. S19). These findings underscore the notable NO activation capability of SmMnOx. On the other hand, the Brønsted acid sites of zeolite plays a substantial role in the synergistic effect between the two components of the mixed catalysts (Fig. S8 and S9). It can be considered that the cooperative mechanism involves the oxidation and activation of NO by SmMnOx to form movable nitrite/nitrite precursors (such as HONO), The mobility of nitrite is supported by some literature, with previous studies demonstrating its thermal stability at 200 °C, which facilitates its transfer [50]. Nitrite may undergo further oxidation when retained on the oxide surface, while such oxidation becomes challenging upon its departure from the oxide surface. Then the nitrite readily translocated to the Cu-LTA zeolites and can be further decomposed under the action of the Brønsted site to be N2 and H2O as reaction products. Moreover, the in situ DRIFT spectra of NO + O2 adsorption unveiled the presence of N2O2 2- species, which is conducive to N2 production, specifically within Cu-LTA. This species may undergo conversion to N2 and H2O via the pathway of N2O2 2- + 2NH2 → 2 N2 + 2 H2O. Of course, the decomposition of NH4NO2 to produce N2 is considered to be the more dominant reaction pathway. However, N2O2 2- species are notably absent in the NO adsorption spectrum of SM/Cu-LTA(m), This could be the reason for the generation of N2O in the NH3-SCR reaction of SM/Cu-LTA(m). Additionally, we conducted a preliminary study on the synthesized of catalyst through sol-gel method and refine its properties through adjustments involving citric acid and other approaches, the resultant catalyst (represented as SM/Cu-LTA(s)(a), the synthesis process is included in SI) exhibited notably enhanced N2 selectivity (Fig. S20). These findings could potentially offer guidance for further exploring the pathway and origins of N2O and enhancing the N2 selectivity of composite catalysts. At the same time, there is no significant consumption of nitrate species adsorbed on Cu-LTA upon exposure to NH3 but a transformation of nitrate species occurs in Fig. 8 d. The monodentate nitrate at 1592 cm−1 is converted into a bridge nitrate at 1605 cm−1, and the nitrate at 1508 cm−1 transforms into a linear nitrate located at 1468 cm−1, the N2O2 2- at 1371 cm−1 and the bridge nitrate at 1228 cm−1 may be consumed [40,51]. This transformation is accompanied by NH3 coordination to Lewis acid sites emerging at 1262 cm−1 and amino species appearing at 1326 cm−1 [52] . These results indicate that the deposition of these nitrates was significantly altered in the SM/Cu-LTA(m) composite catalyst with a small amount of SmMnOx added. Previous investigations have indicated that nitrite exhibits enhanced mobility, particularly favoring its generation on SmMnOx compared to Cu-LTA. During the possible migration and adsorption of nitrite on Cu-LTA, it will also affect the oxidation-reduction dynamics at Cu active sites to rapid driven the Cu+ and Cu2+ redox rather than the formation of Cu+ dimers to Cu2+ species, this can be verified by comparing the consumption rate at 1612 cm−1 (the adsorption of NH3 onto Lewis (copper ions)) when NO + O2 reacts with NH3 in Fig. 9. The consumption rate at 1612 cm−1 in SM/Cu-LTA(m) is more rapidly than that in Cu-LTA, and it consumes more NH3 species within the same amount of time. In order to further compare the reactivity of L-NH3, the attenuation of band and normalized intensity at 1612 cm−1 was recorded as a function of time (Fig. S21). Fig. 9a and b presents the NH3 adsorption spectra on SM/Cu-LTA(m) and Cu-LTA at 180 °C. For Cu-LTA, the L-NH3 (1196, 1261, 1323, 1612 cm−1) and the B-NH4 + (1469 cm−1) are detected. SM/Cu-LTA(m) present similar peaks to Cu-LTA, besides 1454 cm−1 instead of 1469 cm−1 for B-NH4 +. The similar intensity of the IR peaks observed in SM/Cu-LTA(m) and Cu-LTA indicates that NH3 is preferentially adsorbed and activated on the Cu-LTA competent within the composite catalysts. The above phenomenon can be rationalized by the higher concentration of acidic sites present in Cu-LTA, compared to the metal oxide components, as evidenced by the NH3-TPD findings (Fig. 6). At the same time, the spectra of SmMnOx during NH3 adsorption reveal a constrained array of adsorption sites (Fig. S22). When NO + O2 was introduced, the DRIFT spectra of SM/Cu-LTA(m) and Cu-LTA were collected at 180 °C, as shown in Fig. 9c and d. The L-NH3 in SM/Cu-LTA(m) and Cu-LTA decrease upon exposure to NO + O2, displaying the adsorbed NH3 consumed by NO. Moreover, it is worth noting that the B-NH4 + in Cu-LTA did not decrease, but instead showed a slight increase. This observation is in contrast to the apparent depletion of B-NH4 + in SM/Cu-LTA(m). To highlight this contrast, the attenuation of the bands at 1454 cm−1 and 1469 cm−1 with normalized intensities was recorded as a function of time (Fig. S23). These results confirm the previously mentioned reaction pathway of nitrite from SmMnOx to the Cu-LTA can be further decomposed under the action of the Brønsted acid site. The schematic illustration for reaction mechanism of NOx reduction over the SM/Cu-LTA(m) catalyst was supposed in Fig. 10. During the transient reaction between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO + O2, we observed a rapid depletion of nitrate on SM/Cu-LTA(m), which differs from the nitrate accumulation observed on Cu-LTA. This observation suggests that the NH3-SCR reaction unfolding on SM/Cu-LTA(m) follows the “L-H” mechanism. The synergistic mechanism between SmMnOx and Cu-LTA can be regarded as a division of labor and cooperation, with SmMnOx presenting strong activation effect on NO and Cu-LTA exhibiting strong adsorption of NH3, this activation process of NO and NH3 is an essential prerequisite for promoting the SCR reaction. SmMnOx drives the oxidation and activation of NO, resulting in the formation of mobile NO2 -(Eq. 5). The NO2 - then migrates towards the Cu-LTA and reacts with B-NH4 + to form NH4NO2, which decomposes into N2 and H2O (Eq. 7 and 8). The much rapid B-NH4 + consumption in SM/Cu-LTA(m) than Cu-LTA confirms the key role of B-NH4 + in the synergistic effect of NH3-SCR reaction in SM/Cu-LTA(m). In addition, the results of the reaction between pre-adsorbed NO + O2 and NH3 obtained from the in situ DRIFT spectra show that deposition of nitrate might occur on Cu-LTA, while nitrate on SM/Cu-LTA(m) is rapidly consumed upon exposure to NH3. It is speculated that the nitrite intermediates had an impact on the oxidation-reduction dynamics at Cu active sites, thereby attenuating the buildup of inert nitrate and ameliorating nitrate deposition phenomena (Eq. 9–11). In summary, the excellent redox properties of SmMnOx and the abundant acidic sites in Cu-LTA ensure strong NO oxidation/activation and NH3 adsorption capabilities, which promote the rapid consumption of nitrate and adsorbed NH3 species, ultimately achieving higher vehicle exhaust NOx reduction efficiency on SM/Cu-LTA(m). (5) Mn4+-O + NO(g) → NO2 -(ad) + Mn3+ (6) Mn3+ + 1/2O2 → Mn4+ (7) NH4 + + NO2 -→ NH4NO2 (8) NH4NO2 → N2 + 2H2O (9) CuII(OH)(NH3)3 + NO → CuI(NH3)2 + N2 + 2H2O (10) CuII(NH3)4 + NO → CuI(NH3)2 + NH4 + + N2 + 2H2O (11) 2[CuI(NH3)2] +O2 → [(NH3)2 CuII-O2-CuII (NH3)2] 4 Conclusion In summary, we have successfully developed a composite catalytic system with elevated low-temperature activity through compositing Cu-LTA zeolite with a small proportion of SmMnOx metal oxides. Moreover, the promoting pathways and synergistic mechanism between Cu-LTA and SmMnOx have been thoroughly elucidated. The preparation methods and proportions were screened and the optimal condition was mixing SmMnOx and Cu-LTA with a mass ratio of 1:9 for the composite catalyst. Notably, there was a significant enhancement in NOx conversion within the temperature range of 120–240 °C. The synergistic mechanism between Cu-LTA and SmMnOx was elucidated through in situ DRIFT spectra analysis, revealing the presence of an adsorption peak corresponding to an unstable and mobile nitrite intermediate over composite SM/Cu-LTA(m) catalyst. The nitrite species migrate to the Cu-LTA and may be further decomposed into N2 and H2O under the action of the Brønsted acid site. This finding is considered to be the primary reason for the improvement of the NH3-SCR performance. Additionally, it was observed that nitrate deposition was more likely to occur on Cu-LTA, whereas in the case of SM/Cu-LTA(m), the nitrate was likely further converted to achieve high NOx reduction efficiency. Overall, this investigation would help address the challenge of low-temperature performance faced by some zeolite catalysts and provide a novel strategy for the utilization and progression in the field of diesel engine exhaust emission management. coredata.dc:description: Low-temperature selective catalytic reduction of NOx with ammonia (NH3-SCR) over zeolite catalysts remains a great challenge in diesel exhaust purification. Herein, Cu-LTA zeolite with excellent hydrothermal stability was composited with a small proportion of SmMnOx oxides, the composite catalytic system efficiently resolves the low-temperature activity challenge encountered by Cu-LTA. The promoting pathways revealed the presence of active nitrite intermediates formed on SmMnOx by activating NO, that were able to migrate to the Cu-LTA and can be further decomposed on the Brønsted acid sites. Compared to the continuous deposition of nitrates in Cu-LTA, the presence of SmMnOx in composite catalysts efficiently reduced the accumulation of inert nitrate and improved the nitrate deposition phenomena. This innovative research would provide a rational strategy to break the barrier of limited low-temperature performance faced by zeolite catalysts, effectively promoting the NOx removal in vehicles sources.
